PUBHLTH 405 Social Epidemiology of Infectious Disease University of Michigan School of Public Health

Jon Zelner `jzelner@umich.edu` [`epibayes.io`](https://epibayes.io)

![](../images/epid_logo.png){.absolute bottom=0 right=50 width="400" height="100"} ## Agenda :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} - What is an epidemic? - According to the CDC? - According to Rosenberg? - According to us? ::: :::{.column width=50%} ::: ::: ## The different types of infectious disease events according to the CDC :::{.columns} :::{.column width=30%} :::{.nonincremental} - Outbreak - Epidemic - Endemic - Pandemic ::: ::: :::{.column width=70%} - Take 5m in small groups to discuss what differentiates these from each other. - What types of social and historical factors are likely to influence each of these types of events - How are they similar? - How might they differ? ::: ::: ## What does it mean to take dramaturgical perspective ðŸŽ­ on epidemics? :::{.fragment} :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} > "A true epidemic is an event, not a trend." [@rosenberg2020a] ::: :::{.column width=50%} ![1918 Influenza pandemic: An event?](../images/20220907105450.png) ::: ::: ::: ## Epidemic as a play in three acts: 1. Progressive Revelation 2. Managing Randomness 3. Negotiating Public Response ## Progressive Revelation :::{.columns} :::{.column width=40%} > Only when the presence of an epidemic becomes unavoidable is there public admission of its existence. Bodies must accumulate and the sick must suffer in increasing numbers before officials acknowledge what can no longer be ignored. [@rosenberg2020a, p.566] ::: :::{.column width=60%} :::{.r-stack} :::{.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=1} ![Reuters, 12/31/2019](../images/20220907125434.png) ::: :::{.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=1} ![New York Times, 1/20/2020](../images/20220907125243.png) ::: :::{.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=2} ![New York Times, 2/20/2020](../images/20220907110534.png) ::: :::{.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=3} ![Statehouse news bureau, 3/9/2020](../images/20220907124659.png) ::: :::{.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=4} ![bbc.com, 3/11/2020](../images/20220907115712.png) ::: :::{.fragment .fade-in fragment-index=5} ![Only after cases were identified in Michigan was a state of emergency declared here. (clickondetroit.com, 3/11/2020)](../images/20220907115325.png) ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Managing Randomness :::{.columns} :::{.column width=40%} > Accepting the existence of an epidemic implies â€” in some sense demands â€” the creation of a framework within which its dismaying arbitrariness may be managed. Collective agreement on that explanatory framework may be seen as the inevitable second stage in any epidemic. [@rosenberg2020a, pp.567] ::: :::{.column width=60%} ![In the absence of clarity, we can end up with some strange ideas about cause and effect...](../images/20220907111024.png) ::: ::: ## Public Response :::{.columns} :::{.column width=40%} > In the stress of an epidemic..., failure to take action constitutes action. An epidemic might in this sense be likened to a trial, with policy choices constituting the possible verdicts. [@rosenberg2020a, pp.569] ::: :::{.column width=60%} :::{.r-stack} :::{.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=1} ![Action - or lack of action - in an epidemic is clearly a function of the social and political environment of the time in which it takes place.](../images/20220907111453.png) ::: :::{.fragment .fade-in fragment-index=1} ![Outwardly visible signifiers of prevention clearly also have a dramaturgical element](../images/20220907114014.png) ::: ::: ::: ::: ## How can we apply Rosenberg's take to real-world problems? - To what extent do Rosenberg's criteria and those of the CDC align with each other? - Which set of definitions is more useful from a day-to-day perspective? - Could we integrate Rosenberg's ideas into a revised set of guidelines? ## Revising CDC's definitions :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} - We are going to take a shot at doing a bit of what this tweet suggests: - Try to channel some of the ideas from "What is an epidemic?" to revise widely-used CDC definitions and guidance. - Open up [this document](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1KDZubj5-MlLY6K6vLBlRHn1DkMkGg8C8DzerdEIG21Q/edit?usp=sharing) and read the instructions to get started. ::: :::{.column width=50%}

Public health would work better if we stopped mischaracterizing it as an academic field and instead defined it as a necessarily political practice that depends upon synthesizing tools from history, anthropology, epidemiology, geography, planetary sciences, biology, statistics etc

— Eric Reinhart (@_Eric_Reinhart) September 1, 2022
